# Draft:New Zealand Home of the Year Awards

----
The New Zealand Home of the Year Awards are annual awards for New Zealand residential architecture. They were started by HOME Magazine in 1995.
The Awards are open to architects, architectural designers, interior architects, and those working in the design fields. The awards include categories that cover a range of types of residences and are City Home of the Year, Rural Home of the Year, Small Home of the Year, Coastal Home of the Year, Green Home of the Year, Alt & Reno Home of the Year, and Multi-Unit Home of the Year.
Entries open each September, with the awards announced in March of the following year. It is the richest architectural prize in New Zealand, with the overall winner taking home a $10,000 cash prize. Home of the Year has been won by many of New Zealand's most well known architects.
Recent Home of the Year Winners
2025 Home of the Year
* 2025 Home of the Year Winner: Bunker House by Chris Tate Architecture
* Coastal Home of the Year Winner: Onetangi Cliff House by Herbst Architects
* City Home of the Year Winner: Grace by Stevens Lawson Architects
* Small Home of the Year Winner: Kaka Pod by Rafe Maclean Architects
* Rural Home of the Year Winner: Whareora by Dorrington Atcheson Architects
* Multi-Unit Home of the Year Winner: Pocket Houses by Dorrington Atcheson Architects
* Alt & Reno Home of the Year Winner: Light Catcher by Jose Gutierrez Ltd
2024 Home of the Year
* 2024 Home of the Year Winner: Boathouse Bay by Crosson Architects
In 2024, for the first time ever, a multi-unit project took out the Home of the Year Award. Crosson Architects' Boathouse Bay is an enclave of townhouses at Snells Beach, Auckland that explores new ways to consider density.
Category winners in 2024 included: the Rural Home of the Year, Mangwhai Estuary by Belinda George Architects; Green Home of the Year, Back House by Strachan Group Architects; City Home of the Year, Textured Bach by Nic Owen Architects; Alt & Reno Home of the Year, Maungarahiri by Scarlet Architects; Small Home of the Year, Brooklyn MiniFab by Bonnifait + Associates.
2023 Home of the Year
* Home of the Year Winner: Waimauku House by Jo Craddock Architecture
2022 Home of the Year
* Home of the Year Winner:Terrace Edge by Anna-Marie Chin Architects
* City Home of the Year Winner: Clifftops by Bossley Architects
* Alt & Reno Home of the Year Winner: Faith and Doubt, a church conversion by Crosson Architects
2021 Home of the Year
* 2021 Home of the Year[https://homemagazine.nz/home-of-the-year-2021-black-quail-house/ Winner]: Black Quail House by Bergendy Cooke
2020 Home of the Year
* 2020 Home of the Year Winner: Light Mine by Crosson Architects
Older Home of the Year winners include:
Home of the Year 2019 was Diagrid House, designed by Jack McKinney, in Grey Lynn, Auckland. Diagrid House sold in 2025 for $5.5 million.
Home of the Year 2018was Kawakawa House by Herbst Architects, a Piha home nestled amongst pohutukawa.
Herbst Architects' K Valley House, a rustic shed on the Coromandel Peninsula designed for a couple who work in the film industry. In 2025, it was shortlisted for HOME Magazine's Home of the Decade Award.
Home of the Year 2013 was won by Nicholas Stevens and Gary Lawson of Stevens Lawson Architects for a holiday home on Waiheke Island with curving walls and secret doors.
